Scheme 1 Research Paper Single transition metal anchored on defective boron carbide monolayer for efficient and selective CO2 electrochemical reduction: A theoretical study Guanru Xing Investigation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Shize Liu Investigation Methodology Conceptualization Software Visualization Jing-yao Liu Resources Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration * Laboratory of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry, Institute of Theoretical Chemistry, College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130023, P R China Laboratory of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry Institute of Theoretical Chemistry College of Chemistry Jilin University Changchun 130023 P R China Laboratory of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry, Institute of Theoretical Chemistry, College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130023, P R China ⁎ Corresponding author. Electrochemical reduction of CO2 to produce fuels and industrial chemicals shows significant promise for reducing greenhouse gas emission and mitigation the energy crisis. The exploitation of highly efficient catalysts has long been considered an attractive yet challenging task. Herein, we systematically studied the electrocatalytic performance of a range of transition metal (TM) single atom anchored on defective BC3 monolayer, specifically those with a boron vacancy (VB) and a carbon vacancy (VC), named TM@VB and TM@VC, respectively, as single-atom catalysts (SACs) for CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) via density functional theory (DFT). We screened a total of 28 stable SACs by evaluating the formation energy and dissolution potential of metal atoms. Detail reaction mechanisms involved in CO2 reduction process to produce diverse C1 products were considered. Among the 28 candidates, Cu@VB, Mo@VB, Re@VB, Co@VC, and Ir@VC displayed remarkable efficiency in reducing CO2 into HCOOH at nearly zero or extremely low limiting potentials (U L) of -0.01 ∼ 0 V. These SACs exhibit excellent electrocatalytic activity, surpassing most previously reported catalysts. Furthermore, these five SACs effectively suppressed the competing hydrogen evolution reaction, highlighting their high selectivity toward HCOOH. In addition, the volcano relationship between the ∆G *HCOO and U L was established. This work may offer a promising strategy for the research and development of high-efficiency CO2RR electrocatalysts, which has potential implications for addressing environmental and energy challenges. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction Density functional theory Single-atom catalysts Defective BC3 monolayer Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The over-reliance on non-renewable fossil fuels has resulted in massive emissions of CO2, causing severe climate changes and a global carbon unbalance. Thus, the conversion of CO2 into valuable and useful products could make an important contribution to the global sustainable development [1–3]. Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is an exceptionally attractive method because it can be powered by renewable electricity and conducted under mild reaction conditions [4–6]. However, the strong chemical inertness of the CO2 molecule makes the activation of its C = O bond quite challenging. Consequently, there is an urgent demand for electrocatalysts to promote CO2RR. Transition metals (TM) such as Pt , Au , Ag , Cu have the capability to reduce CO2 into C1 product (CO, HCOOH, CH3OH, or CH4) [7–9]. However, these pure metals typically have problems with high overpotential, low product selectivity, and poor Faradaic efficiency. For example, polycrystalline Cu has been proven to be the most extensively used metal catalysts for CO2 conversion to CH4, but it requires a high overpotential of up to -1 V [10–13]. Furthermore, in aqueous environments, the competing hydrogen evolution reaction ( HER ) can easily occur, reducing the selectivity and efficiency of CO2RR [14]. Hence, it is of great significance to exploit electrocatalysts with excellent activity and selectivity for CO2RR. In recent years, the emergence of single-atom catalysts (SACs) has opened up new prospects in heterogeneous catalysis [15–17]. Compared with traditional bulk metal catalysts, SACs possess some unique features, such as low metal content, extremely high atom utilization, long-term stability, high catalytic activity and product selectivity [18,19]. Benefiting from these features, SACs have demonstrated to be high-performance electrocatalysts in numerous electrochemical reactions [20–22]. For SACs, the choice of support material is one of the crucial factors affecting the catalytic activity. The support for SACs must not only stabilize the active single metal atoms and prevent their aggregation, but also adjust the substrate to promote charge transfer between the active center and the reactants, thereby tuning the activity of the catalysts. Two-dimensional (2D) materials offer many advantages, including a large specific surface area, unique electronic structures and diverse structures, making them promising support materials for SACs [23]. To date, various SACs based on 2D materials and their derivatives have shown potential as CO2RR electrocatalysts, such as metal-doped graphene, graphitic carbon nitride, boron nitride, graphdiyne and so on [24–35]. For example, graphene supported single TM atoms like Cr, Fe, Ni, and Pt have proven high catalytic activity toward CO2RR [24–27]. Cui et al. reported that TM@C2N were promising CO2RR catalysts for generating CH4 (TM = Ti, Mn) and CH3OH (TM = Fe, Co, Ni, Ru), with low overpotentials of 0.58 ∼ 0.80 V [28]. Fan et al. synthesized atomic Ru immobilized on porous hexagonal boron nitride, exhibiting enhanced catalytic performance for CO2 reduction to CH4 compared to Ru nanoparticles [31]. Recently, a novel graphene-like layered BC3 has been successfully prepared on the Nb B 2 ( 0001 ) surface using carbon substitution technique [36]. Subsequently, the electronic structure, mechanical properties, and magnetic properties of BC3 have been extensively investigated [37–39]. It has been found that monolayer BC3 has great potential in applications such as in lithium-ion battery [40], photocatalysis [41], hydrogen storage [42], and gas sensors [43]. Similar to other 2D materials, for example graphene, BC3 can also regard as a support for SACs and has demonstrated excellent catalytic activity in oxygen evolution reactions (OER), oxygen reduction reactions (ORR), and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [44–46]. As a support for SACs, defects are a promising means to enhance the metal-support interactions [47]. For BC3, there are two types of single defects on the surface, namely B defects and C defects, corresponding to two different coordination environments for metals, leading to different catalytic activity. Therefore, in this study, we investigated the influence of different microenvironments and active centers on the catalytic performance of CO2RR. We designed a range of defective BC3 monolayer supported single TM as SACs, in which 17 different 3d/4d/5d TM atoms (TM = Cr ∼ Cu, Mo ∼ Ag, W ∼ Au, expect radioactive element Tc) were chosen to construct catalysts. The thermodynamic and electrochemical stability of 34 SACs were assessed though computing the formation energy and dissolution potential. The most favorable CO2RR pathways of electrochemical CO2 hydrogenation to different C1 products, including CO, HCOOH, CH3OH, and CH4, were obtained. The calculation results indicate that Cu@VB, Mo@VB, Re@VB, Co@VC, and Ir@VC have superior catalytic activity with very low limiting potential and high selectivity toward HCOOH. 2 Computational methods Spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) [48,49] computations were conducted by using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [50,51]. The projected augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials were used to describe the electron and core interactions. The Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was utilized to calculate the exchange-correlation energy [52]. A plane-wave basis set with an energy cut-off of 450 eV was used for valence electrons. During the structure optimization, the convergence thresholds for energy and atomic force were set to 10−5 eV and 0.02 eV/Å, respectively. The 3 × 3 × 1 and 9 × 9 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-points meshes were employed for geometric optimizations and electronic structure analysis, respectively [53]. The empirical Grimme's DFT − D 3 correction was employed to describe the van der Waals interactions between adsorbates and the catalyst [54]. A 15 Å vacuum space along the z-direction was set to avoid the interaction between periodic images. The thermal stability of the BC3 monolayer was assessed via Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations [55] for 10 ps at 400 K. The VASP implicit solvent model was employed to account for the solvent effects [56,57]. Changes of Gibbs free energies (ΔG) was computed by the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model [58], and computational details are given in the Supporting Information. The limiting potential ( U L ) of CO2RR is defined by the following formula U L = − Δ G PDS / e where ΔG PDS is the free energy change of the potential determined step ( PDS ). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure, stability, and electronic property The optimized unit cell of the pristine BC3 sheet is displayed in Fig. S1a, which consists of 6 C atoms and 2 B atoms. The calculated lattice parameter of BC3 is 5.17 Å, and the bond lengths of C-B and C-C are 1.57 Å and 1.42 Å, respectively, which are in good accordance with previous reports [37,44]. A 3×3×1 supercell of BC3 was adopted to construct the metal atom doped BC3 monolayer. Two kinds of single vacancy can be introduced on pristine BC3, namely B vacancy (VB) and C vacancy (VC), as illustrated in Fig. S1b and c. The formation possibility of VB and VC on BC3 was evaluated using the vacancy formation energy ( E vf ), calculated by the following formula E vf = E V − E P + E B / C Where E V and E P refer to the total energies of BC3 with and without vacancy, respectively, and E B / C represents the energy of a single B or C atom in pristine borophene or graphene. The calculated E vf values for VB and VC are 5.54 and 4.40 eV, respectively, which are much smaller than E vf for a single vacancy in graphene (7.45 eV) [59]. This indicates that the formation of VB and VC is thermodynamically feasible. As depicted in Fig. 1 , we considered 17 TM atoms to be anchored on VB-BC3 and VC-BC3 monolayers, denoted as TM@VB and TM@VC, respectively. To assess the thermodynamic and electrochemical stability of these 34 catalysts, we computed the formation energy ( E f ) and dissolution potential ( U diss ) (Fig. 2 ) using the following expressions: E f = E TM @ B C 3 − E V − B C 3 − E TM U diss = U diss 0 ( metal , bulk ) − E f / n e where E TM @ B C 3 and E V − B C 3 represent the total energies of TM@BC3 and VB/C-BC3, respectively, and E TM refers to the energy of a single TM atom in the most stable bulk structure. U diss 0 ( metal , bulk ) represents the standard dissolution potential of bulk metal and n refers to the number of transferred electrons during dissolution. The values of E f and U diss are summarized in Table S1. Note that E f < 0 indicates that the SACs is thermodynamically stable, while U diss > 0 indicates that the SACs is electrochemically stable. Fig. 2a shows that expert for Cr, Mn, Fe, Mo, W, and Re@Vc, the remaining 17 TM@VB and 11 TM@VC meet both criteria of E f < 0 and U diss > 0, suggesting that they are both thermodynamically and electrochemically stable. Consequently, 17 kinds of TM@VB SACs and 11 kinds of TM@VC SACs were screened out for further investigations. In order to reveal the bonding characteristic and stabilizing nature of TM@VB/C SACs, the electron localization function (ELF) was calculated. In general, the larger the ELF value, the stronger the local electron distribution. Taking Co@VB and Co@VC as examples (Fig. 2b and c), the ELF values for the TM–C and TM–B bonds fall between 0.6 and 0.7, indicating a covalent nature in the TM–C and TM–B bonds. Moreover, it can be seen from the projected density of states (PDOS) in Figs. S2 and S3 that the hybridization between the TM-d and C/B-2p orbitals is clear, which reflects that the interaction between TM atoms and the substrates is strong. As electronic conductivity is vital for electrocatalysts, we calculated the total density of states ( TDOS ) to examine the conductivity of all TM@VB/C. It can be seen from Figs. S4 and S5 that for all TM@VB/C SACs, there are the electronic states distribution at the Fermi level, indicating good electronic conductivity. 3.2 CO2RR mechanism on TM@VB/C The electrochemical CO2RR involves multiple proton-coupled electron transfer ( PCET ) steps. The possible reaction pathways for CO2 reduction into CO, HCOOH, CH3OH, and CH4 are depicted in Scheme 1 . The optimized intermediate structures and free energies of possible intermediates adsorbed on 28 SACs were computed. The corresponding Gibbs free energy profiles are depicted in Figs. 3-5 and Figs. S6-S8. Additionally, the most stable adsorption structures of the CO2RR intermediates on TM@VB (TM = Mn, Fe, Mo, Ru, Os, and W) are presented in Fig. S9. Based on the potential C1 products, 28 SACs can be classified into two groups. The first group consists of TM@VB (TM = Cr ∼ Cu, Mo, Rh, Pd, Ag, Re, Ir, Pt, and Au) and TM@VC (TM = Co ∼ Cu, Ru ∼ Ag, and Os ∼ Au) (Figs. 3, 4 and Figs. S7-S9), where HCOOH is the main product. The second one comprises TM@VB (TM = Ru, Os, and W) (Fig. 5 ), which are capable of reducing CO2 into multiple C1 products under the same potential. 3.2.1 CO2 reduction to HCOOH The initial protonation process in CO2RR can form two different intermediates, i.e., *COOH/*HCOO (CO2 → *COOH/*HCOO). In the case of Mn@VB (Fig. 3a), the generation of *HCOO is more thermodynamically preferred than that of *COOH in the first hydrogenation reaction, the ΔG values are 0.17 and 1.24 eV, respectively. It is noteworthy that *COOH tends to adsorb in a monodentate pattern (with one C atom binding to the Mn atom), while *HCOO adsorbs in a bidentate mode (with two O atoms binding to the Mn atom) (Fig. S10), implying that Mn atom has strong oxygen affinity. Subsequently, the hydrogenation of *COOH and *HCOO directly leads to the 2e− product HCOOH instead of adsorbed *HCOOH. Additionally, the produced *COOH can continue to be hydrogenated to *CO and H2O with a ΔG of 0.04 eV. Then, *CO is further converted to *CHO with an uphill ΔG of 0.11 eV or easily released from the Mn@VB surface with a ΔG of -0.67 eV. Notably, the generation of the *COOH intermediate needs a high energy input (1.24 eV), making it unfavorable to produce other C1 products (CO, CH3OH and CH4) via the *CO intermediate. As a result, further hydrogenation steps were not considered. Therefore, HCOOH stands as the primary product of CO2RR on Mn@VB, and the PDS is *HCOO → HCOOH, the corresponding U L is -0.25 V. Similar situation can be observed on TM@VB (TM = Cr, Rh, Pd, Ag, and Pt) and TM@VC (TM = Pd, Ag, and Au) (Fig. S7). For Cr@VB, Rh@VB, Pd@VB, Pd@VC, and Ag@VC, the PDS corresponds to the first PCET step CO2 → *HCOO with the U L of -0.84, -0.97, -0.27, -0.47, and -0.28 V, respectively, while for Ag@VB, Pt@VB, and Au@VC, the second hydrogenation step *HCOO → HCOOH serves as the PDS, with corresponding U L of -0.28, -0.47, and -0.36 V, respectively. Moreover, the protonation processes on Fe@VB (as shown in Fig. 3b), and TM@VB (TM = Co, Ni, Cu, Ir, and Au), as well as TM@VC (TM = Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, and Pt) (Fig. S8) are similar to that of Mn@VB. However, the difference is that there exists a stable *HCOOH adsorption configuration on these catalysts. For TM@VB (TM = Fe, Co, Ni, Ir, and Au), the U L are -0.21, -0.63, -0.14, -0.59, -0.14, respectively. For TM@VC (TM = Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, and Pt), the U L are -0.27, -0.12, -0.58, -0.24, and -0.16 V, respectively. Note that in the case of Cu@VB, no applied potential is required to reduce CO2 into HCOOH, i.e., the two protonation processes are exothermic. For Mo@VB (Fig. 4), the generation of HCOOH through the *HCOO species is more advantageous in CO2RR than the formation of CO through *COOH. The PDS for producing HCOOH is *HCOO → *HCOOH, with the U L of -0.01 V. However, unlike the above situation, the hydrogenation of *HCOOH (0.34 eV) is more energetically favorable than its desorption (0.62 eV). This indicates that CO2 may be reduced to 6e− product CH3OH and 8e− product CH4. The optimal reaction pathways of CH3OH and CH4 generations are CO2 → *HCOO → *HCOOH → *H2COOH → *CH2O → *CH2OH → *CH3OH → CH3OH and *CH3OH → *CH3 → CH4, respectively. The step of *HCOOH → *H2COOH is identified as the PDS for the production of CH3OH and CH4, and the corresponding U L is -0.34 V. A similar situation is also observed on Re@VB, Co@VC, Os@VC, and Ir@VC (Fig. S9). By comparing the U L of these different C1 products, it can be concluded that the HCOOH remains the most favorable product in CO2 reduction on Mo@VB, Re@VB, Co@VC, Os@VC, and Ir@VC. 3.2.2 CO2 reduction to multiple C1 products Fig. 5 depicts the various CO2RR pathways on TM@VB (TM = Ru, Os, and W). For Ru@VB (Fig. 5a), the first protonation of CO2 gives priority to the production of *COOH. Next, *HCOOH and *CO are formed via *COOH intermediate. Since *HCOOH and *CO are weakly adsorbed, they are relatively easy to release from the Ru@VB surface as the 2e− products. Compared with the desorption process, the protonation processes of *HCOOH and *CO are also energetically preferred, the ΔG of *HCOOH → *CHO and *CO → *CHO are 0.31 and 0.03 eV, respectively. Then, the production of *CH2O from *CHO (ΔG = 0.24 eV) is more favorable than the formation of *CHOH (ΔG = 0.49 eV). Starting from *CH2O, CH3OH and CH4 can be produced through consecutive downhill steps. The PDS for HCOOH and CO is the same, that is, CO2 → *COOH, and the U L is -0.23 V. Regarding the products CH3OH and CH4, the PDS is *HCOOH → *CHO with U L of -0.31 V. For Os@VB (Fig. 5b), the protonation step of *HCOO → HCOOH is determined as the PDS for HCOOH product, and the U L is -0.37 V. The reduction of CO2 to *CO is a spontaneous process, while the desorption of *CO has a maximum ΔG of 0.82 eV. At the same time, the formed *CO can also be further reduced to *CHO species, and this step needs to overcome a small free energy barrier of 0.11 eV. Starting from *CHO, two products CH3OH and CH4, can be formed with the same PDS (*CHO → *CH2O), and the U L is -0.14 V. For W@VB (Fig. 5c), four products, including CO, HCOOH, CH3OH, and CH4, are produced with the same PDS (CO2 → *COOH), and the U L is -0.27 V. These results demonstrate that for TM@VB (TM = Ru, Os, and W), CO2 can be reduced into multiple C1 products, indicating that they have poor product selectivity. Thus, these three candidate catalysts are not suitable for the desired application. Additionally, through the above CO2RR free energy diagrams of TM@VB/C, we observed that ΔG for each hydrogenated step of CO2 reduction to HCOOH scales linearly the ΔG *HCOO. Consequently, the volcano relationship between the limiting potential and Δ G * HCOO was established, as shown in Fig. 6 . In the presence of the adsorbed HCOOH configuration, the CO2RR process is hindered by the step from CO2 to *HCOO when ΔG *HCOO > 0 eV, while the step of *HCOO → *HCOOH becomes the PDS when ΔG *HCOO < -0.17 eV. In the absence of the *HCOOH configuration, the first PCET step, i.e., CO2 → *HCOO, is identified as the PDS when ΔG *HCOO > 0.21 eV, while the PDS shifts to the step of *HCOO → HCOOH when ΔG *HCOO < 0.21 eV. Among these catalysts, Cu@VB, Mo@VB, Re@VB, Co@VC, and Ir@VC are located at the top of the volcano plot, indicating high catalytic activity. Therefore, these five SACs are screened out as good CO2RR electrocatalysts with the limiting potential of 0, -0.01, 0, 0, and 0 V, respectively, which are significantly superior to the Cu(211) surface (-0.32 V) [60]. 3.3 Competition between CO2RR and HER on TM@VB/C In general, CO2RR occurs in an aqueous environment, and HER is its predominant competing reaction. Due to the significant consumption of H+/e− pairs by both CO2RR and HER, and their shared active sites, the occurrence of HER can lead to a reduction in the Faraday efficiency of CO2RR. Consequently, the Gibbs free energy of HER on TM@VB/C SACs were calculated. The U L of the predominant CO2 reduction products and HER are summarized in Table S2. To assess the selectivity of CO2RR, the difference in the limiting potential between CO2RR and HER on these SACs was calculated. As shown in Fig. 7 , except for Au@VC, the U L(CO2RR) – U L(HER) values for the remaining catalysts are all positive, which indicates that these SACs exhibit higher selectivity for CO2 reduction over HER. 3.4 Electronic structure analysis The adsorption ability of the active center TM atoms on the key intermediates plays an essential role for the CO2RR catalytic activity. As mentioned above, TM@VB (TM = Cu, Mo, Re) and TM@VC (TM = Co, Ir) possess the highest catalytic activity toward HCOOH. It is noteworthy that on these five catalysts, the generation of HCOOH occurs exclusively through the *HCOO intermediate rather than *COOH, mainly because *HCOO binds more strongly to the catalyst than *COOH. To elucidate the underlying mechanism for the stronger adsorption of *HCOO than *COOH, we performed the electronic structure analysis. Taking Cu@VB as an example, the PDOS in Fig. 8a and b clearly shows that the hybridization between O-2p orbital of *HCOO and Cu-3d orbital is stronger than that of *COOH in the range of -1 to -8 eV. This result can also be well confirmed by the charge density difference, as shown in Fig. 8c and d. Furthermore, it is found that there are more electrons are transferred from Cu@VB to *HCOO (0.62|e|) compared to *COOH (0.30|e|) by Bader charge calculations. This may explain the strong adsorption of *HCOO on Cu@VB. The same situation is also found for the other four systems, as plotted in Figs. S11-S14. Although it is predicted that Cu@VB, Mo@VB, Re@VB, Co@VC, and Ir@VC are high-performance SACs for CO2RR, they have not been experimentally synthesized yet. To further assess the thermal stability of these five candidates, AIMD simulations were performed at 400K for 10 ps. As seen in Figs. 9 and S15, the temperature and total energy fluctuate around the equilibrium states, and the geometric structures of Cu@VB, Mo@VB, Re@VB, Co@VC, and Ir@VC are preserved well after 10 ps, guaranteeing the high stability of these five catalysts. Conclusion In sum, we theoretically studied the CO2RR electrocatalytic performance of 34 kinds of TM anchored on defective BC3 monolayer containing single vacancies in either a B or C atom. The calculated E f and U diss show that 28 TM@VB/C configurations exhibit high thermodynamic and electrochemical stability. Based on the free energy profiles, 25 TM@VB/C tend to reduce CO2 into the product HCOOH, while Ru@VB, Os@VB, and W@VB are capable of reducing CO2 into multiple C1 products. Among them, Cu@VB, Mo@VB, Re@VB, Co@VC, and Ir@VC demonstrate excellent catalytic activity in promoting HCOOH generation, almost spontaneous processes. The optimal reaction pathway is CO2 → *HCOO → *HCOOH → HCOOH. The positive values of U L(CO2RR) – U L(HER) for these five catalysts indicate their high HCOOH selectivity for HCOOH production. Furthermore, AIMD simulations suggest that these five SACs possess good thermal stability, establishing them as highly effective CO2RR electrocatalysts. Moreover, the ∆G *HCOO can be used as a descriptor to establish a volcano plot with the U L. We hope that this work can give a valuable reference for the further exploitation of novel electrocatalysts for CO2RR. coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical reduction of CO2 to produce fuels and industrial chemicals shows significant promise for reducing greenhouse gas emission and mitigation the energy crisis. The exploitation of highly efficient catalysts has long been considered an attractive yet challenging task. Herein, we systematically studied the electrocatalytic performance of a range of transition metal (TM) single atom anchored on defective BC3 monolayer, specifically those with a boron vacancy (VB) and a carbon vacancy (VC), named TM@VB and TM@VC, respectively, as single-atom catalysts (SACs) for CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) via density functional theory (DFT). We screened a total of 28 stable SACs by evaluating the formation energy and dissolution potential of metal atoms. Detail reaction mechanisms involved in CO2 reduction process to produce diverse C1 products were considered. Among the 28 candidates, Cu@VB, Mo@VB, Re@VB, Co@VC, and Ir@VC displayed remarkable efficiency in reducing CO2 into HCOOH at nearly zero or extremely low limiting potentials (U L) of -0.01 ∼ 0 V. These SACs exhibit excellent electrocatalytic activity, surpassing most previously reported catalysts. Furthermore, these five SACs effectively suppressed the competing hydrogen evolution reaction, highlighting their high selectivity toward HCOOH. In addition, the volcano relationship between the ∆G *HCOO and U L was established. This work may offer a promising strategy for the research and development of high-efficiency CO2RR electrocatalysts, which has potential implications for addressing environmental and energy challenges.
coredata.dc:title: Single transition metal anchored on defective boron carbide monolayer for efficient and selective CO2 electrochemical reduction: A theoretical study
